Authors:
Joyce Eberhart, Gregory Michael Bonito, James M.
Trappe
Title:
Tuber luomae, a new spiny-spored truffle species from the
Pacific Northwest, USA, with a diagnosis of the similar European T.
malacodermum
Keywords:
Ascomycota, Pezizales, Tuberaceae, phylogeny, Rufum clade,
hypogeous fungi, truffle
Abstract:
Tuber luomae, a new truffle species from the Pacific
Northwestern USA, is distinguished by spiny-spores and a thick peridial
pellis of inflated, globose to subpolygonal cells. ITS sequence analyses
show that this species has phylogenetic affinity to other Tuber species
in the Rufum clade and is apparently endemic to the Pacific Northwestern
region of the USA and adjacent Canada. The only other member of the
Rufum clade with a strongly developed peridium of large, inflated cells
is the southern European T. malacodermum. A diagnosis of its type
collection is presented for comparison with T. luomae. The holotype of
T. malacodermum is more than a century old and was preserved in ethanol,
but a recent collection from Spain yielded good DNA for sequencing.
Phylogenetic analysis shows these two species on different branches
within the Rufum clade.
